head.title: To Save One Twin, or Lose Both

hedline.hl1: To Save One Twin, or Lose Both

abstract.p: Rabbi Jonathan H Gerard letter on Rev Robert A Sirico's Sept 28 article defends effort to save one conjoined twin rather than let both die

block.p: The Rev. Robert A. Sirico calls the court decision to sacrifice one Siamese twin to save the other ''a clear evil'' (Op-Ed, Sept. 28). The court, he says, ''has turned its back on a tenet that the West has stood by: Life, no matter how limited, should be protected.'' But in calling for the protection of both babies, joined at the pelvis, he would make it likely that both will die.

The Rev. Robert A. Sirico calls the court decision to sacrifice one Siamese twin to save the other ''a clear evil'' (Op-Ed, Sept. 28). The court, he says, ''has turned its back on a tenet that the West has stood by: Life, no matter how limited, should be protected.'' But in calling for the protection of both babies, joined at the pelvis, he would make it likely that both will die.

For one who believes that Heaven is the goal of life, this may be desirable. But this is not the only ''tenet that the West has stood by.'' Judaism, no less than Roman Catholicism, seeks to protect the sanctity of human life. But its world view that we should not rely on Heaven to make everything right commands a different response. One of the children should live.
(Rabbi) JONATHAN H. GERARD Easton, Pa., Sept. 28, 2000
